text: Riverside Drive. Entrance at 72nd St. looking north. William J. McAlpin supervising engineer. Sept. 30, 1879. Deposited uith NYPL by NYC Park Dept. 1931.

title: The Chatsworth and Annex, 72nd Street and Riverside Drive

text:
Riverside Park: The West 72nd Street entrance. This photograph appeared in a brochure published by the Department of Parks on the occasion of the opening of the West Side Improvement Project on October 12, 1937.

1908.

Gift of Department of Parks.
title: Manhattan: Riverside Park - 72nd Street (West).

text: Hudson River monument, Riverside Drive & 72d St. Designed by Allen G. Newman, Sc. Cast by Jno. Williams, Inc. 1909. Photographer: A. B. Sogart, 80 E. 14th St.

Riverside Park: The marginal lands and New York Central Railroad tracks as viewed northward from West 72nd Street. Compare this with view taken in 1937 at the completion of the West Side Improvement Project; this photograph being published in a brochure at that date.

1915.

Gift of Department of Parks.
title: Manhattan: Riverside Park - 72nd Street (West).

text:
A general view of Midtown - West Side as photographed southeastward from atop an apartment building in the vicinity of Riverside Drive and West 72nd Street. The gas holders in the right center are at 60th Street east of West End Avenue. To their left are the outstanding structures rising in the Columbus Circle area.

1922

Ewing Galloway
title: General view - Midtown - West side.

text:
Riverside Drive and Park, north from West 72nd Street. The spacious home at the right is the Charles M. Schwab mansion. This occupies the entire block bounded by the Drive, West End Avenue, between 73rd and 74th Streets. Beyond, are the 12-story Lombard (erected 1907-8), No. 332 West End Avenue and the massive Athorpe Apartments (erected 1924-5), No. 2201-17 Broadway. Construction of the latter date this view.

1908

Gift of I. N. P. Stokes

Riverside Park, north from West 72nd Street, showing the marginal lands prior to improvement and landscaping.

The major feature of this project will be the enclosure of the New York Central Railroad Tracks. At the dock at 79th Street lay the "Buccaneer" and the "Constitution."

No. 2 shows construction details of the 74th-75th area. No. 3 is from the original vantage point. Note here the U. S. Fleet at anchor and on display, also the absence of the old ships shown in View 1.

View1: March 19, 1930
View2: July 11, 1931
View3: June 11, 1934

P. L. Sperr
title: Manhattan: Riverside Park - 72nd Street (West).

title: Manhattan: Riverside Park - 72nd Street (West).

text:
Riverside Park:

1. Riverside Drive, north from but not including 72nd Street, showing the Schwab Residence in the background. March 19, 1930. P. L. Sperr.

2. The overhead pedestrian crossing at the foot of West 72nd Street. March 19, 1930. P. L. Sperr.

Riverside Park:

1. Riverside Drive, north from but not including 72nd Street, showing the Schwab Residence in the background. March 19, 1930. P. L. Sperr.

2. The overhead pedestrian crossing at the foot of West 72nd Street. March 19, 1930. P. L. Sperr.

Riverside Park, north from West 72nd Street, showing the New York Central Railroad tracks, prior to enclosure as a portion of the West Side Improvement Project.

Note the wooden forms in position and the concrete retaining walls resulting from same. In 1937 a top will be installed and the extension of the Henry Hudson Parkway run on same. This, in conjunction with major landscaping jobs will radically change the appearance.

View 1: July 11, 1931
View 2: April 3, 1932
View 3: June 1, 1934

P. L. Sperr

title: Manhattan: Riverside Park - 72nd Street (West).

text:
Riverside Drive, south from 77th to and including 72nd Streets. (Riverside Drive begins at 72nd Street,)

June 11, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

Riverside Park: The marginal lands and the enclosed viaduct that covers the New York Central Railroad tracks as viewed northward from W. 72nd Street. Note the radical changes effected in this area by the West Side Improvement Project which at this point was under the joint auspices of the Department of Parks and the Railroad Company. Compare this photograph with one taken in 1915 from this vantage point, both being incorporated in a brochure published by the Park Department on October 12, 1937.

Samuel H. Gottscho
Gift of Department of Parks

1937.
title: Manhattan: Riverside Park - 72nd Street (West).

text:
Riverside Park: The West 72nd Street entrance after completion of the West Side Improvement Project. Note the radical changes from 1908. This photograph was included in a brochure published by the Department of Parks on the completion and opening of this Project on October 12, 1937.

1937.

Gift of Department of Parks
title: Manhattan: Riverside Park - 72nd Street (West).
